and i'm a software engineer at microsoft

and i'm rodrigo rodriguez and i'm a

so to start us off let's talk about what
we hope you get out of this presentation
we're going to demonstrate the current
ability of webassembly applications to
discover and use iot devices on
kubernetes
we also hope to illustrate the delta
between what the webassembly systems
interface supports today and the
potential of what it can support in the
future as it matures
and then finally we are going to show
how awkry simplifies iot device

so to break down those goals into an

an iot scenario that we hope to enable

and the second being porting ocry from

application of webassembly modules

finally we'll just show the outcome in a

discuss next steps

deploy some frame server pods in a

that frame server is grabbing the frames

identify
those coyotes and passes that output to
a final alerting pod that tells you to

so this all works
but
a lot of farms are in very remote places

latency
and so you decide to follow the laws of

so before we talk about how we
implemented the device plug-in manager
and uh crestlet let's first talk about
what the device plug-in framework is
so out of the box kubernetes has several
compute resource types namely cpu
ram and huge pages and this is why
kubernetes is powerfully declarative
because you can apply a pod to your
cluster and specify that it needs this
much cpu and this much ram in order on
the node to be reserved for it in order
to run and so you know that that
workload's going to have exactly the
resources it needs
the device plug-in framework takes that
one step further and allows you to
advertise other node level resources to
cubelet so that then they can be
requested in a pod just as you would
compute resources and this was really
motivated by gpu access you can see here
that we have a gpu device plugin that's
advertising that as a resource to the
node and then we have a gpu pod that's
requested in this container spec on the
side
and ocry uses this framework for when it
discovers devices it then creates device
plugins to represent them
and
thereby when it automatically deploys
applications it requests those resources
and so that's why we needed then to
implement the device plug-in framework
in crestlit and so i got the opportunity
to take on this work and what this meant
was
basically reverse engineering and
porting
the traditional kubernetes cubelets
device plug-in manager which is written
in go
and implementing that in rust in
crestlet which is a kubernetes cubelet
written in rust
and what this work entailed was
implementing the registration service
for device plug-ins and crestlet and
also making it so that crestlet updates
the node spec with that available
resource
once a device plug-in registers and then
finally that the crestlet reserves that
device plug-in resource for
the requesting container when it is
scheduled to the node
and then the step beyond this and what's
really cool about the device plug-in
framework is that a device plug-in can
specify exactly what
enviro environment variables it once
injected and what files it needs mounted
to any pod that requests that resource
and so this means that now we have just
with this work a scenario where
webassembly modules can declaratively
request devices
on kubernetes clusters and the crestlet
um will mount any of those files that
are needed environment variables into
the webassembly module or thereby
grant access to the webassembly module
for those files

once you apply that to your cluster the

tell the appropriate discovery handler
to start looking for those devices
whether locally on the node or across
the network
for every device that the discovery
handler discovers and reports back to
the awkry agent the agent will create a
device plugin for it thereby advertising
that device to the cubelet and the
cluster at large as a requestable
resource the agent also creates our
second second custom resource the awkry
instance to represent the device in its
usage so we now have this inventory of
the devices that ocari has discovered
and finally our last component is the
awkry controller
what it does is when it sees an instance
it will automatically deploy the
workload that was specified in the
configuration to use that instance and
request the device plugin that was
created by the agent thereby deploying a
pod that has all the resources and
connectivity information that it needs
to connect to
that device
